basics.name: Mohammad Jasim Usmani
basics.label: Data Scientist/Machine Learning Engineer
basics.summary: A Data Scientist and Machine Learning Researcher holding a Master’s degree, backed by over 3+ years of experience, specializing in the design and development of ML models/products in the NLP, time series and computer vision domain for various applications.

work.name: Precision Medicine Group
work.summary: Working with LLMs to build RAG pipelines, ETL pipelines with Snowflake and Matillion
highlights: Collaborated in building end-to-end ETL pipelines using AWS, Snowflake, and Matillion for ingesting data from APIs in type 2 SCD tables.
Collaborated with cross-functional teams to ingest data in SF and develop a streamlit app for holiday calendar for employees world wide, resulting in a 30% reduction in scheduling conflict.

Developed a RAG pipeline to automatically process JSON, pdf and CSV files in Snowflake to store in vector database to solve business problems, delivering data-driven solutions in recommendation systems for sales team.
Assisting in developing and maintaining vector database for various AI applications.

work.name: Aerospace Robotics Lab, Concordia University
work.summary: Project: Accelerating Graph Neural Networks for Real Time Physics Simulation
highlights: Developed a novel algorithm and framework for training AI model using Graph neural network to predict rovers or vehicles escape when stuck in sand in real-time.
Implemented the rigid body correction for graph neural network prediction during inference which led to an accuracy of 94.7 %
Accelerated the runtime of the model by 3x (from 0.34 seconds per frame to 0.12 seconds) while retaining the accuracy.

work.name: CRIM (Computer Research Institute of Montreal)
work.summary: Project: Object Detection in satellite images using Diffusion Models
highlights: Using GPU cluster for parallel training large diffusion models on MS COCO dataset.
Fine tuning of diffusion based object detection to improve the accuracy and generalization on satellite images.
Acheived mAP of 0.89 (higher the better, between 0 and 1) for the object detection on satellite images (detection of cars, houses, trees from satellite images).

work.name: APER Lab, JMI
work.summary: Project: Optimization of Power Transfer in Photovoltaic Panels
highlights: Designed and simulated a fuzzy logic controller to share power between two solar powered buildings.
Captured an extra 900W solar power from the two buildings with the designed controller.
Published journal paper in IEEE transactions on Industry Applications (IF: 4.4).

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

education.area: Electrical and Computer Engineering - Machine Learning and AI

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
